p: First, academics, often highly influential proponents of environmentalism, for the most part do not like being confrontational. Guided by an ideology that encourages objectivity, many scientists, scholars, and educators are reluctant about getting involved in advocacy (Gamson 1999; Milkoreit et al. 2015). However, Martin Luther King Jr. wrote, “freedom is never voluntarily given by the oppressor; it must be demanded by the oppressed” (“Letter from Birmingham Jail” 1963). The environmental crisis is a problem of unequal distribution of resources due to the unequal distribution of power. Yet instead of challenging that power, we opt for non-confrontational approaches like changing diets and modes of transportation. And since environmental organizations are increasingly funded by private interests, challenging those interests can create considerable risk professionally.
